qas.question: Who was in charge of Lithuania's Communist Party in 1989
What party did  Lithuania's Communist Party break apart from?

answers.text: Communist Party of the Soviet Union

qas.question: Who was in charge of the loyalist faction?
What place's control was the Communist Party of Lithuania out from under after the split?
Who visited with the hope of bringing back the Communist Party of Lithuania to the Soviet Party?

context: On December 7, 1989, the Communist Party of Lithuania under the leadership of <a0_0>Algirdas Brazauskas<a0_0/>, split from the <a1_0>Communist Party of the Soviet Union<a1_0/> and abandoned its claim to have a constitutional "leading role" in politics. A smaller loyalist faction of the Communist Party, headed by hardliner <a2_0>Mykolas Burokevičius,<a2_0/> was established and remained affiliated with the CPSU. However, Lithuania’s governing Communist Party was formally independent from <a3_0>Moscow's<a3_0/> control – a first for Soviet Republics and a political earthquake that prompted <a4_0>Gorbachev<a4_0/> to arrange a visit to Lithuania the following month in a futile attempt to bring the local party back under control.
